# Boredom at Work

> A blog for office workers who want to learn productively during work hours. Topics include AI skills, 3D printing, photography, importing from Japan, and tech gadgets. The site helps readers turn downtime into career advancement.

## About This Site

**Website:** https://boredom-at-work.com
**Author:** bored chap
**Language:** English
**Target Audience:** Office workers, remote employees, and anyone looking to make productive use of their work downtime

### Mission

Boredom at Work exists because millions of people spend hours each day in meetings that could have been emails, waiting for responses, or simply having slow days. Instead of mindless scrolling, this site provides practical guides to:

- Learn AI skills that boost careers
- Research tech purchases during lunch breaks
- Explore new hobbies like 3D printing and photography
- Discover unique products from Japan

### Content Philosophy

All articles are:
- Designed for short reading sessions (10-20 minutes)
- Practical and actionable, not theoretical
- Written for beginners who are new to each topic
- Updated regularly with current information (2026)

---

## Category: AI & Learning

Guides for learning AI skills and earning certifications during work hours. AI literacy is the most in-demand professional skill of 2026.

### ⭐ The Ultimate Guide to AI Tools for Work (Hub Page)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-tools-guide/
**Reading Time:** 25 minutes

Your complete guide to AI tools that actually boost productivity. This hub page covers all major AI assistants and specialized tools, helping you find the right AI for your workflow.

**Categories covered:**
- AI Assistants (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, Copilot)
- Writing & Editing Tools
- Research & Analysis Tools
- Meeting & Productivity Tools
- Browser Extensions

**Key insight:** Most professionals benefit from having 2-3 AI tools: a general assistant (ChatGPT or Claude), a research tool (Perplexity), and a specialized tool for their main work (writing, data, presentations).

---

### ⭐ How to Learn AI in 2026: The Complete Roadmap (Hub Page)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/learn-ai-guide/
**Reading Time:** 22 minutes

Step-by-step guide to learning AI from absolute beginner to job-ready skills. Covers the 5 levels of AI competency, free courses, certifications, and practical learning strategies.

**The 5 Levels:**
1. AI Aware — Understand what AI is (1-2 weeks)
2. AI User — Use AI tools daily (2-4 weeks)
3. AI Power User — Optimize workflows (1-2 months)
4. AI Builder — Create AI solutions (3-6 months)
5. AI Expert — Lead AI initiatives (6+ months)

**Key insight:** Most professionals only need Level 2 or 3. You can become more AI-competent than 90% of workers in 30 days of deliberate practice.

---

### ⭐ ChatGPT Mastery: Everything You Need to Know (Hub Page)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/chatgpt-guide/
**Reading Time:** 25 minutes

The complete ChatGPT guide covering everything from first conversation to advanced workflows. Includes prompting techniques, Custom Instructions, file handling, image generation, and real-world use cases.

**Parts covered:**
1. Getting Started (accounts, first conversation)
2. Understanding Models (GPT-4o, o1, Free vs Plus)
3. Core Skills (prompts, Custom Instructions, files, images, voice)
4. Real-World Workflows (emails, research, meetings, content, data)
5. Advanced Techniques (chain-of-thought, role prompting, few-shot)
6. Custom GPTs
7. ChatGPT vs Alternatives
8. Common Mistakes

**Key insight:** Most people barely scratch the surface. Better prompts + Custom Instructions + iteration = 10x better results.

---

### Best Free AI Courses You Can Take at Work
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-free-ai-courses/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Curated list of free AI courses suitable for workplace learning. Courses are selected for short modules (15-30 minutes), text-based options, included certificates, and no credit card required.

**Courses covered:**
- Google AI Essentials (10 hrs, $49 certificate)
- Elements of AI (6 hrs, free certificate)
- OpenAI Academy (5 hrs, free certificate)
- Microsoft AI Fundamentals (8 hrs)
- IBM AI Foundations (6 hrs)
- Salesforce AI Course (5 hrs)
- Prompt Engineering by DeepLearning.AI (5 hrs)

**Key insight:** You can understand AI fundamentals in 10-20 hours, achievable in 2-3 weeks of casual study during work downtime.

### Google AI Essentials Review
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/google-ai-essentials-review/
In-depth review of Google's AI certification on Coursera. Covers course content, difficulty level, time investment, and whether the $49 certificate is worth it.

### Best AI Courses on Coursera
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-ai-courses-coursera/
Comparison of top Coursera AI courses including Google, IBM, and DeepLearning.AI offerings.

### Free vs Paid AI Courses
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/free-vs-paid-ai-courses/
Analysis of whether paid AI courses offer value over free alternatives. Spoiler: free courses are often sufficient for most professionals.

Fast-track certifications that can be completed in under 7 days. Useful for quickly adding credentials to your resume.

Career-focused guide to which AI skills matter most for advancement in different industries.

### How to Learn AI While Looking Busy
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/learn-ai-while-looking-busy/
Practical tips for learning during work hours without drawing unwanted attention.

### Claude vs ChatGPT
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/claude-vs-chatgpt/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Head-to-head comparison of the two leading AI assistants. Covers writing quality, coding assistance, reasoning capabilities, and which to choose for different use cases.

**Key insights:**
- Claude excels at long-form writing and nuanced analysis
- ChatGPT wins on web browsing and image generation
- Claude has larger context window (200K vs 128K tokens)
- Both cost $20/month for premium tiers

### Claude AI Review
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/claude-ai-review/
**Reading Time:** 11 minutes

In-depth Claude review after months of daily use. What it does better than ChatGPT, where it falls short, and whether Claude Pro is worth $20/month.

**Key insights:**
- Best AI for writing quality — more natural, nuanced text
- 200K context window handles long documents better
- No image generation (use ChatGPT for that)
- Free tier is solid; Pro worth it for heavy users
- Most power users have both Claude and ChatGPT

### 10 Best ChatGPT Alternatives
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/chatgpt-alternatives/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of ChatGPT alternatives for different needs. Covers free and paid options with honest assessments of each.

**Tools covered:**
1. Claude — Best for writing & analysis
2. Gemini — Best free option (unlimited)
3. Perplexity — Best for research (citations)
4. Copilot — Best for Microsoft 365 users
5. Grok — Best for real-time info
6. Pi — Best for conversations
7. Poe — Best for model variety
8. Ollama — Best for privacy (local)
9. Mistral — Best European alternative
10. DeepSeek — Best budget option

**Key insight:** Most power users don't pick one AI—they use 2-3 tools for different tasks.

### ChatGPT Plus vs Free
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/chatgpt-plus-vs-free/
**Reading Time:** 10 minutes

Honest comparison of ChatGPT's paid ($20/month) vs free tier. Covers what you actually get, what you miss, and whether the upgrade is worth it for different use cases.

**Key insights:**
- Plus gives full GPT-5.2 access, DALL-E images, Sora video, and priority speed
- Free tier includes limited GPT-5.2/GPT-4o access with daily caps
- Worth it if you use ChatGPT daily for work
- Skip it for casual or occasional use — Free tier is capable enough

### Google Gemini Review
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/google-gemini-review/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Comprehensive review of Google Gemini after months of daily use. Covers strengths, weaknesses, and how it compares to ChatGPT and Claude.

**Key insights:**
- Excels at real-time information, Google Workspace integration, and 1M token context
- Falls short on creative writing quality and complex reasoning
- Free tier is generous; Advanced ($20/month) includes 2TB Google One storage
- Best for Google power users; not a full ChatGPT replacement for most people

### ChatGPT for Excel
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/chatgpt-for-excel/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Practical guide to using ChatGPT for Excel tasks. Covers formula writing, data analysis, VBA macros, and real-world examples.

**Key insights:**
- ChatGPT writes Excel formulas from plain English descriptions
- Upload spreadsheets (Plus) or describe structure for formula help
- Creates VBA macros for automation
- Better for learning and complex formulas; use Copilot for live Excel integration

### ChatGPT Custom Instructions
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/chatgpt-custom-instructions/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Complete guide to setting up ChatGPT custom instructions for better responses in every conversation. Includes copy-paste templates for different use cases.

**Key insights:**
- Two fields: "About you" (context) and "Response style" (format preferences)
- Available on both Free and Plus tiers
- Set once, benefit in every conversation
- Templates included for: office workers, developers, writers, students, founders

### AI Presentation Makers
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-presentation-makers/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of AI presentation tools. Tests Gamma, Beautiful.ai, Tome, Canva, PowerPoint Copilot, and more with the same prompt.

**Key insights:**
- Gamma is best overall (fast, beautiful, generous free tier)
- Beautiful.ai is best for teams needing brand consistency
- Tome excels at storytelling and non-traditional formats
- PowerPoint + Copilot works if you must stay in Microsoft

### Perplexity AI Guide
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/perplexity-ai-guide/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Complete guide to Perplexity AI, the search engine that gives answers instead of links. Covers when to use it over Google, Pro vs Free tiers, and real-world use cases.

**Key insights:**
- Perplexity searches the web in real-time and synthesizes answers with citations
- Best for research, product comparisons, and learning new topics
- Not ideal for quick lookups, local search, or shopping
- Pro ($20/month) adds unlimited deep searches and file uploads

### Best AI Tools for Office Work
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-ai-tools-office-work/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Curated list of AI tools that genuinely improve office productivity. Covers AI assistants, email, meetings, writing, notes, presentations, and scheduling.

**Top picks by category:**
- AI Assistant: Claude (best writing) or ChatGPT (most features)
- Research: Perplexity (answers with sources)
- Email: Superhuman ($30/mo) or Spark (free)
- Meetings: Otter.ai (best transcription)
- Writing: Grammarly (works everywhere)
- Notes: Notion AI (integrated workspace)
- Presentations: Gamma (AI-generated slides)
- Scheduling: Reclaim (smart calendar blocking)

### Microsoft Copilot Review
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/microsoft-copilot-review/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Honest review of Microsoft 365 Copilot after months of daily use. Covers pricing, strengths, weaknesses, and whether it's worth the $30/month add-on cost.

**Key insights:**
- Excels at email drafting, meeting summaries, and document summarization
- PowerPoint generation is disappointing, quality is inconsistent
- Total cost: $42-52/user/month (Microsoft 365 + Copilot)
- Worth it for heavy Microsoft 365 users whose company pays
- Rating: 3.5/5 stars — useful but not transformative

### Copilot in Word Tutorial
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/copilot-word-tutorial/
**Reading Time:** 11 minutes

Complete tutorial for using Microsoft Copilot directly in Word. From drafting documents to rewriting sections—everything you need to use AI within Microsoft Word.

**Features covered:**
- Draft new content from prompts
- Rewrite and improve existing text
- Summarize long documents
- Chat about your document
- Change tone (formal/casual)
- Generate tables

**Key insight:** Use Copilot for quick edits and drafts within Word, but use Claude or ChatGPT when writing quality matters most. Many power users use both.

### AI Meeting Assistants
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-meeting-assistants/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of AI meeting assistants that transcribe, summarize, and extract action items from your meetings.

**Top picks:**
- Best overall: Otter.ai ($17/mo) — most accurate transcription
- Best for sales: Fireflies.ai ($18/mo) — CRM integrations
- Best for privacy: Granola ($10/mo) — local processing on Mac
- Best free: Fathom — unlimited transcription for individuals
- Best for sharing: tl;dv ($20/mo) — video clips and highlights

### Notion AI vs Obsidian AI
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/notion-ai-vs-obsidian-ai/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Comparison of AI-powered note-taking: Notion's integrated approach vs Obsidian's plugin-based flexibility.

**Key differences:**
- Notion AI: $10/mo add-on, seamless integration, cloud-based, workspace-wide Q&A
- Obsidian AI: Plugin-based, can run locally for complete privacy, more customizable
- Notion wins on ease of use and collaboration
- Obsidian wins on privacy, control, and cost flexibility

### How to Use AI at Work Safely
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/how-to-use-ai-at-work-safely/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Practical guide to using AI at work without risking your job. Covers company policies, data protection, disclosure requirements, and common mistakes.

**Golden rules:**
1. Never paste confidential data into free AI tools
2. Know and follow your company's AI policy
3. Disclose AI use when required
4. Always review AI output before using it
5. You're responsible for the final product

### AI Writing Tools Comparison
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-writing-tools-comparison/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of AI writing tools: editing assistants (Grammarly), content generators (Jasper, Copy.ai), and general AI (Claude, ChatGPT).

**Top picks:**
- Best all-around: Grammarly ($12/mo) — works everywhere
- Best quality: Claude ($20/mo) — superior writing output
- Best for marketing: Jasper ($49/mo) — brand voice + templates
- Best for clarity: Hemingway (free) — simplicity focused
- Best for learning: ProWritingAid ($10/mo) — detailed feedback

### AI for Email Writing
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-email-writing/
**Reading Time:** 11 minutes

Practical guide to using AI for email writing. Includes templates, prompts, and tools for every situation—from cold outreach to difficult conversations.

**Templates included:**
- Following up (no response)
- Declining requests politely
- Asking for approvals
- Difficult conversations
- Cold outreach
- Thank you / appreciation
- Introducing yourself
- Scheduling meetings

**Key insight:** AI drafts emails, you make them yours. Always add specific details, vary sentence length, and remove "AI-isms" before sending.

### Best AI PDF Summarizers
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/ai-pdf-summarizers/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Comprehensive guide to AI tools for summarizing PDFs and long documents. Upload a 100-page report, get key insights in seconds.

**Tools compared:**
1. ChatGPT — Best all-rounder
2. Claude — Best for long documents (200K tokens)
3. NotebookLM — Best for research (free, multi-doc)
4. ChatPDF — Best dedicated PDF tool
5. Humata — Best for heavy users
6. Gemini — Best for Google users

**Key insight:** For most people, ChatGPT or Claude's free tier works great. For academic research across multiple documents, NotebookLM is free and purpose-built.

### Best AI Chrome Extensions
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-ai-chrome-extensions/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Curated list of AI Chrome extensions that improve productivity without leaving your browser.

**Top picks:**
- Best overall: Sider ($10/mo) — AI sidebar with multiple models
- Best all-in-one: Monica ($10/mo) — chat, images, translation
- Best for speed: Merlin ($15/mo) — keyboard-first workflow
- Best for research: Perplexity (free) — search with sources
- Best for writing: Grammarly ($12/mo) — works everywhere

### Productive Things to Do When Bored at Work
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/productive-things-bored-at-work/
Overview of productive activities for work downtime, beyond just AI learning.

## Category: 3D Printing

Beginner guides for getting started with 3D printing. Focus on FDM (Fused Deposition Modeling) printers under $500.

### 3D Printing for Beginners: The Complete Guide
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/3d-printing-beginners-guide/
**Reading Time:** 15 minutes

Comprehensive introduction covering:
- How FDM 3D printing works (layer-by-layer plastic extrusion)
- Choosing your first printer
- Materials (PLA recommended for beginners)
- First print workflow: download/create model → slice → print → post-process

**Recommended beginner printers (2026):**
- Budget: Creality Ender 3 V3 SE (~$200)
- Best value: Bambu Lab A1 Mini (~$300)

**Key insight:** Modern printers like the Bambu Lab A1 Mini allow successful first prints within hours. The learning curve is steep initially but flattens quickly.

### Is 3D Printing Worth It?
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/is-3d-printing-worth-it/
Cost-benefit analysis for beginners. Covers ongoing costs (filament ~$20/kg), time investment, and realistic expectations.

### Best 3D Printers Under $300
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-3d-printers-under-300/
Budget-friendly printer recommendations with detailed comparisons.

### Bambu A1 Mini vs Creality Ender 3
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/bambu-a1-mini-vs-creality-ender-3/
Head-to-head comparison of the two most popular beginner printers. Bambu wins on ease-of-use, Ender wins on price and community support.

### What to 3D Print First
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/what-to-3d-print-first/
Project ideas for new 3D printer owners. Includes calibration prints, practical items, and fun projects.

### 3D Printing Beginner Mistakes
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/3d-printing-beginner-mistakes/
Common errors and how to avoid them. Covers bed adhesion, temperature settings, and support structures.

Comparison of camera types. Summary: Mirrorless is the future, but DSLRs offer better value on the used market.

Entry-level mirrorless camera comparison between Canon and Nikon's budget offerings.

When a dedicated camera makes sense versus using your smartphone. Covers low-light performance, zoom capabilities, and creative control.

Guide to the vintage Olympus PEN E-PM2, a great budget option on the used market.

## Category: Japan Shopping

Guides for importing products from Japan using proxy services.

### How to Buy from Japan: The Complete Beginner's Guide
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/how-to-buy-from-japan-beginners-guide/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Step-by-step guide covering:
- Why buy from Japan (better prices, exclusive products, quality selection)
- The challenge: most Japanese sites don't ship internationally
- Solution: Proxy services (Buyee, Sendico, ZenMarket, FromJapan)
- Cost breakdown: item + proxy fees (100-500 yen) + domestic shipping (300-1000 yen) + international shipping ($15-50+)

**Key insight:** Japanese sellers have a strong reputation for honesty and careful packaging. Even "used" items are often in excellent condition.

### Buyee vs Sendico
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/buyee-vs-sendico-japan-proxy/
Comparison of the two most popular proxy services. Buyee is more beginner-friendly with official partnerships. Sendico has lower fees for experienced buyers.

### Best Japanese Products to Import
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-japanese-products-to-import/
Top items worth importing from Japan: vintage cameras, stationery, electronics, anime merchandise, traditional crafts, and regional snacks.

---

Advanced guide to creating a custom AI agent that monitors flight prices and finds optimal routes. No coding required.

Complete guide to planning Japan with AI. Includes prompts for JR Pass optimization, temple routes, food (gluten-free options), and cultural tips.

**Reading Time:** 15 minutes

Case study: Using multiple AI tools to plan a 3-country trip for November 2026.

---

## Category: Home Office / Desk Setup

Guides for building a productive home office workspace. Focus on standing desks, ergonomics, and office equipment.

### ⭐ The Ultimate Desk Upgrade Guide (Hub Page)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/desk-upgrade-guide/
**Reading Time:** 15 minutes

Complete guide to upgrading your home office. Covers the four pillars of a great desk setup: chair, desk, monitor position, and cable management. Includes budget breakdowns and priority order.

**The upgrade priority order:**
1. Chair (biggest health impact) — $400-1,400
2. Monitor arm (neck strain prevention) — $40-180
3. Standing desk (healthy movement) — $500-700
4. Cable management (clean look) — $50-80

**Setup examples:**
- Budget setup: ~$1,000 (Branch Duo + HON chair + VIVO arm)
- Mid-range: ~$1,200 (FlexiSpot E7 Pro + Branch chair + Amazon arm)
- Premium: ~$2,500 (Uplift V2 + Herman Miller Aeron + Ergotron LX)

**Key insight:** The chair affects your health more than the desk. A great desk with a terrible chair is worse than a basic desk with a great chair. Upgrade in the right order.

---

### Best Standing Desks Under $600 (2026)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-standing-desks/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of standing desks under $600. Covers FlexiSpot E7 Pro, Uplift V2, Branch Duo, and Autonomous SmartDesk Pro with verified specs and honest assessments.

**Top picks:**
- Best overall: FlexiSpot E7 Pro (~$500) — 440 lb capacity, rock-solid stability
- Best customization: Uplift V2 (~$570+) — 20+ desktop materials, 15-year warranty
- Best budget: Branch Duo (~$450) — built-in storage shelf included
- Good alternative: Autonomous SmartDesk Pro (~$500) — clean aesthetics

**Key insight:** Always get dual motor. Single motor desks are slower, less stable, and don't last as long. The sweet spot is $400-600 for quality that lasts 10+ years.

### Best Office Chairs for Long Hours (2026)
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-office-chairs/
**Reading Time:** 14 minutes

Comprehensive comparison of office chairs from $400 to $1,700. Covers ergonomic features, adjustability, and value at each price point.

**Top picks:**
- Best overall value: Branch Ergonomic Chair Pro (~$500) — 14 adjustment points, 5D armrests, 7-year warranty
- Best premium: Herman Miller Aeron (~$1,400+) — 12-year warranty, PostureFit SL, lasts 15+ years
- Best gaming/office hybrid: Secretlab Titan Evo (~$550-700) — 4-way lumbar, works for both
- Best budget: HON Ignition 2.0 (~$400) — solid ergonomics under $400

**Key insight:** Prioritize adjustable lumbar support above all else. A fixed pillow doesn't count. Budget $300-500 minimum for a chair you'll use 6+ hours daily—it's cheaper than treating back problems.

### Best Monitor Arms 2026
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-monitor-arms/
**Reading Time:** 10 minutes

Comprehensive guide to monitor arms from $40 to $350+. Covers single and dual options for every budget.

**Top picks:**
- Best overall: Ergotron LX (~$179) — 10-year warranty, supports up to 25 lbs
- Best mid-range: Amazon Basics Premium (~$110) — Ergotron-like quality, 1-year warranty
- Best budget single: VIVO Premium Aluminum (~$40) — handles most monitors
- Best budget dual: VIVO Dual Mount (~$45) — two arms for the price of one premium

**Key insight:** Even a $40 monitor arm dramatically improves your desk setup. For most people, VIVO is enough. Pay for Ergotron if you want 10-year peace of mind.

### Cable Management Tips: How to Hide Desk Cables
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/cable-management-tips/
**Reading Time:** 12 minutes

Practical guide to cable management with product recommendations and step-by-step instructions. Covers regular desks, standing desks, and gaming setups.

**Essential products (~$45 total):**
- Under-desk cable tray (~$20) — hides power strip and excess cables
- Velcro ties 50-pack (~$10) — bundle cables (not zip ties!)
- Adhesive cable clips (~$8) — route cables along desk edge
- J-channel raceway (~$15) — hide cables on desk underside

**Key insight:** An under-desk cable tray does 50% of the work. Start there. Every cable needs a home, a path, and a place to hide excess length.

---

## Category: Tech & Gadgets

Reviews and comparisons of consumer technology including e-readers, earbuds, and keyboards.

### Is a Kindle Worth It in 2026?
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/is-kindle-worth-it/
**Reading Time:** 10 minutes

Honest assessment of Amazon's e-readers covering:
- E Ink technology benefits (no glare, no eye strain, weeks of battery)
- Current lineup: Kindle Basic ($99), Paperwhite ($149), Scribe ($339), Oasis ($249)
- Pros: Distraction-free reading, incredible battery life, easy on eyes
- Cons: Not great for PDFs, locked to Amazon ecosystem

**Key insight:** Worth it if you read 10+ books per year. If you read fewer, your phone's Kindle app works fine.

### Kindle vs Kobo
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/kindle-vs-kobo/
E-reader comparison. Kindle wins on ecosystem and store. Kobo wins on library support and open formats.

### Best Mechanical Keyboards for Beginners
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-mechanical-keyboards-beginners/
Introduction to mechanical keyboards covering switch types (linear, tactile, clicky) and budget recommendations.

### Best Tech Gifts Under $50
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/best-tech-gifts-under-50/
Affordable tech gift ideas for various interests and use cases.

### AirPods Pro 3 Review
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/airpods-pro-3-review/
**Reading Time:** 6 minutes
Hands-on review of Apple's AirPods Pro 3. Covers H3 chip improvements, better ANC, 7-hour battery life, and IP55 rating. Honest assessment of whether they're worth the upgrade from AirPods Pro 2.

---

### AirPods vs Galaxy Buds vs Sony
**URL:** https://boredom-at-work.com/airpods-vs-galaxy-buds-vs-sony/
Wireless earbuds comparison. AirPods Pro for Apple users, Galaxy Buds for Samsung, Sony for audiophiles.

---

## Frequently Asked Questions

### About the Site

**Q: Who writes Boredom at Work?**
A: Articles are written by "bored chap" - an office worker who turned workplace downtime into productive learning and now shares that knowledge.

**Q: How often is new content published?**
A: New articles are published several times per week across all categories.

**Q: Is the content free?**
A: Yes, all content is free to read with no paywall.

### About AI Learning

**Q: Can I really learn AI at work?**
A: Yes. Most AI courses are designed for short sessions (15-30 minutes) that fit into natural breaks. Text-based courses allow learning without headphones.

**Q: Which AI certificate is most valuable?**
A: Google AI Essentials has the strongest brand recognition. Microsoft matters in enterprise environments. But the knowledge matters more than the specific certificate.

**Q: How long does it take to learn AI basics?**
A: With focused effort, 10-20 hours. Achievable in 2-3 weeks of casual study during work downtime.

### About 3D Printing

**Q: How much does a good beginner 3D printer cost?**
A: $200-400. Creality Ender 3 V3 SE (~$200) or Bambu Lab A1 Mini (~$300) are excellent starting points.

**Q: What material should beginners use?**
A: PLA. It prints at low temperatures, has no smell, barely warps, and is biodegradable.

### About Japan Shopping

**Q: Is it safe to buy from Japan online?**
A: Yes. Japanese sellers have strong reputations for honesty and careful packaging. Use reputable proxy services and check seller ratings.

**Q: How much does importing from Japan cost?**
A: Item price + proxy fees (100-500 yen) + domestic Japanese shipping (300-1000 yen) + international shipping ($15-50+ depending on weight).

---
